_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Buckeye Texas HUB was constructed in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) #58 and meets the (2014 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is this facility's policy to follow the most current future editions to the extent feasible and adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and Local codes/laws. If an emergency were to occur, it is the Facility's policy to contact the Nueces County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) as well as the Refinery Terminal Fire Company, as appropriate. Medical emergencies will require notification of Corpus Christi Medical Center. This facility maintains a trained incipient stage fire response and first-responder operations level hazardous materials response team to respond to the initial stages of an emergency.



The Buckeye Texas HUB facility is a refined petroleum product storage and distribution facility. The Risk Management Program (RMP) covers the LPG distribution and storage system only, including the associated piping, Vessels, Barge loading/offloading and truck loading/offloading stations.



The Worst Case and Alternate Case release scenarios were evaluated. Additionally, the local Emergency Response Action Plan was updated to reflect the liquefied propane and butane system response requirements.



The Buckeye Texas HUB Facility complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D-Program Level 3). Additionally, this plan meets the requirements of the U.S. Department of Labor - Occupational Safety and Health Administration's Process Safety Management regulations inclusive of all 14 elements) for Highly Hazardous Chemicals (29 CFR Part 1910.119).



This Facility has never had an accident involving the Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage system resulting in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in-place.



In the event of an emergency involving the Buckeye Texas HUB LPG Storage system, it is

the policy of the Facility to initially contact the Refinery Terminal Fire Company and request their assistance. The Facility's Emergency Response Action Plan is coordinated with the Refinery Terminal Fire Company and the Nueces County LEPC. The Facility is fully secured with fencing and controlled access in accordance with its site security plan.



Buckeye continually evaluates the process for opportunities to improve safety. As such, a global operating procedure and maintenance program has been developed and maintained. Also, Buckeye is implementing a corporate-wide policy to include the local first responders in regular exercises and in all 3 year PSM/RMP training cycles.
